content.text: (a) The student suspends a mass \(m=100 \mathrm{~g}\) from the spring
She measures, and records in Table 1.1, the stretched length \(l\) of the spring, as indicated in Fig. 1.1
Describe two techniques for measuring the length of the spring, to ensure an accurate reading. You may draw a diagram
1 A student investigates the behaviour of a spring, and then uses the spring to determine the mass of an object
The apparatus is shown in Fig. 1.1
(b) She repeats step (a) for values of \(m=200 \mathrm{~g}, m=300 \mathrm{~g}, m=400 \mathrm{~g}\) and \(m=500 \mathrm{~g}\). Her readings are shown in Table 1.1
Plot a graph of \(l / \mathrm{cm}\) ( \(y\) -axis) against \(m / \mathrm{g}\) ( \(x\) -axis)
Start the axes from the origin (0,0)
Draw a best-fit straight line. The line might not go through the origin
(c) Use your graph to determine the length \(l_{0}\) of the spring with no load on it
(i) On Fig. 1.2, measure the stretched length \(l_{\mathrm{X}}\) of the spring
(ii) Use the graph and your reading from (d)(i), to determine the mass \(m_{\mathrm{X}}\) of object \(\mathbf{X}\). Show clearly on the graph how you obtained your answer
(d) An object \(\mathbf{X}\) is suspended from the spring
2 A student investigates the effect of insulation on the cooling of water
He uses the apparatus shown in Fig. 2.1
Beaker A is covered with material that is a thermal insulator
Beaker B is identical to beaker A but has no insulation
(e) Two students measure the mass of another object using the same method and apparatus. One student records the mass as 132.6 g . The other student records the mass as 130 g
State and explain which answer has the more suitable number of significant figures for this experiment
statement
explanation
(f) (i) A student wants to eliminate, from the comparison, any thermal energy lost from the surface of the water
Suggest a change to the equipment which will do that
(ii) Suggest what effect this change will have on the cooling rates of the water in beaker A and beaker B
(i) Draw a normal to point \(\mathbf{N}\), extending above \(\mathbf{AB}\). Label the upper end of the normal with the letter \(\mathbf{L}\)
(ii) The student draws line \(\mathbf{EN}\) as shown in Fig. 3.1
On Fig. 3.1, measure the acute angle \(\theta\) between the lines \(\mathbf{LN}\) and \(\mathbf{EN}\)
An acute angle is an angle of less than \(90^{\circ}\)
\(\theta =\)
(a) The student places a transparent block \(A B C D\) near the centre of the ray-trace sheet as indicated in Fig. 3.1
(i) Measure distance \(d\) between pins \(\mathbf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathbf{P}_{2}\)
(ii) State whether the two pins are a suitable distance apart for accurate ray tracing. Explain your answer
statement
explanation
(b) The student places two pins \(\mathbf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathbf{P}_{2}\) on line \(\mathbf{EN}\) as shown in Fig. 3.1
(c) The student views the images of \(\mathbf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathbf{P}_{2}\) through the block

He places two pins \(\mathbf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathbf{P}_{4}\) so that pins \(\mathbf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathbf{P}_{4}\) and the images of \(\mathbf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathbf{P}_{2}\) all appear exactly one behind the other
Draw a line through \(\mathbf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathbf{P}_{4}\). Extend this line to meet \(\mathbf{CD}\)
Label the point at which this line meets \(\mathbf{CD}\) with the letter \(\mathbf{F}\). Label the lower end of this line with the letter \(\mathbf{G}\)
Extend line \(\mathbf{EN}\) to approximately 5 cm below line \(\mathbf{CD}\)
Label the point at which this line crosses \(\mathbf{CD}\) with the letter \(\mathbf{H}\). Label the lower end of this line with the letter \(\mathbf{J}\)
(d) (i) Measure the acute angle \(\alpha\) between lines \(\mathbf{CD}\) and \(\mathbf{GF}\)
\(\alpha =\)
Measure the acute angle \(\beta\) between lines \(\mathbf{CD}\) and \(\mathbf{JH}\)
\(\beta =\)
(ii) A student suggests that angle \(\alpha\) should be equal to angle \(\beta\)
State whether your results support this suggestion. Justify your answer by reference to values from your results
statement
justification
(e) Describe two techniques to use in this type of experiment to ensure results are accurate
(f) Suggest one reason why different students, all doing this experiment carefully, may not obtain identical results
3 A student investigates the refraction of light by a transparent block
The student's ray-trace sheet is shown full-size in Fig. 3.1
4 A student investigates the resistance of a wire
Plan an experiment which enables him to investigate how the length of a wire affects the resistance of the wire
Resistance \(R\) is calculated from the equation: \(R=\frac{V}{I}\)
where \(V\) is the potential difference (p.d.) across the wire and \(I\) is the current in the wire
The apparatus available includes:
- a selection of wires
- a variable power supply
- an ammeter
- a voltmeter
In your plan:
- list any additional apparatus needed
- complete Fig. 4.1 to show a voltmeter connected to measure the potential difference across the wire
- explain briefly how to do the experiment, including the measurements to take so that the resistance can be determined
- state the key variables to keep constant
- draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display the readings (you are not required to enter any readings in the table)
- explain how to use the readings to reach a conclusion
